org.beiter.michael.crypto4j.primitives

Class SecureRandomFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.beiter.michael.crypto4j.primitives.SecureRandomFactory

  • public final class SecureRandomFactory
extends Object
    A factory to create instances of objects that implement the SecureRandom interface.

    • Method Summary

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static SecureRandom getInstance(SecureRandomSpec prngSpec)
                                throws NoSuchAlgorithmException,
                                       FactoryException
        Returns a new instance of SecureRandom with the provider and algorithm configured in the provided configuration object.

        When sharing the object returned by this method across several threads, configure the JCA subsystem to only use thread safe algorithm implementations, or utilize appropriate locking mechanisms in your code to prevent concurrent access.

        Parameters:
        prngSpec - The prngSpec to initialize the instance with
        Returns:
        An instance of SecureRandom
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - When prngSpec is null
        NoSuchAlgorithmException - When the random number generator is not available
        FactoryException - When the configured provider is not registered in the security provider list

      • getSingleton

        public static SecureRandom getSingleton(SecureRandomSpec prngSpec)
                                 throws NoSuchAlgorithmException,
                                        FactoryException
        Returns a singleton instance of SecureRandom with the provider and algorithm configured in the provided configuration object. Note that different singletons are returned for permutations of the provided algorithm and provider settings.

        Retrieving a singleton by this method will cause the factory to keep state, and store a reference to the singleton for later use. Use the singleton for low utilization use cases only, as there may be congestion otherwise. Getting a singleton object is slightly faster than getting a pooled object, and also reduces memory overhead, which makes using a singleton the go-forward approach unless the singleton cannot handle the computational load in multi-threaded applications.

        Additional notes

        • When sharing the object returned by this method across several threads, configure the JCA subsystem to only use thread safe algorithm implementations, or utilize appropriate locking mechanisms in your code to prevent concurrent access.
        • You may reset the factory state using the reset() method to retrieve a new / different singleton the next time this method is called.
        • If you need tight control over the singleton, including its lifecycle and configuration, then you should create such objects with the getInstance() method and maintain their state as "singletons" in your application's business logic.
        • Note that there is no "seeded" variant of this method, because fully reseeding a SecureRandom PRNG is not possible: Any provided seed supplements, rather than replaces, the existing seed, thus guaranteeing to never reduce randomness.
        Parameters:
        prngSpec - The prngSpec to initialize the instance with
        Returns:
        An instance of SecureRandom
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - When prngSpec is null
        NoSuchAlgorithmException - When the random number generator is not available
        FactoryException - When the configured provider is not registered in the security provider list

      • getPooledInstance

        public static SecureRandom getPooledInstance(SecureRandomSpec prngSpec,
                                             PoolSpec poolSpec)
                                      throws NoSuchAlgorithmException,
                                             FactoryException
        Returns a pooled instance of SecureRandom. Initializing SecureRandom can be very time consuming, and (based on the local Java security configuration) may be even blocking. Using a ThreadLocal instance to reduce the impact of problem without introducing congestion on a shared object can be very problematic in an application server that reuses threads, and can lead to memory leaks and security issues. To improve performance on object management, and avoid repeated JCA "create" calls, this method provides access to an object pool that manages shared object instances.

        This method allows borrowing an object from a pool of SecureRandom with the provider and algorithm configured in the provided configuration object. In other words, when requesting an object of a specific configuration, this methods creates the necessary pooling infrastructure, properly configures the pool, and pre-populates it if needed. Note that different object configurations may use different object pools. However, once a pool for a specific object configuration has been created, the pool and object configuration can not be changed without resetting this factory. In other words, the pool spec for existing object specs is ignored in subsequent calls to this method, but a new object spec leads to creation of a new pool with that pool spec. See reset() on how to reset the factory.

        The object must be returned to the pool once it is not longer needed to prevent pool starvation! See the returnPooledInstance(SecureRandomSpec, SecureRandom) method on how to return objects to the pool.

        Retrieving an object by this method will cause the factory to keep state, and store a reference to the object pool for later use. Use the object pool to create a set of objects for sharing across multiple threads. This is less memory efficient than using a singleton, but allows an application to control object congestion. Set the pool size to a value smaller than the number of concurrently active threads, and use pooled objects over singletons in high utilization use cases. Getting a pooled object is slightly slower than getting a singleton.

        The pool spec object controls how this factory manages the object pool. Chose the correct configuration and pool size (if needed) based on the expected utilization and congestion of the returned SecureRandom object pool in your application.

        See getSingleton(SecureRandomSpec) for additional notes, in particular for the thread safety requirements that particularly apply when sharing singletons across threads.

        Parameters:
        prngSpec - The spec to initialize the instances with
        poolSpec - The spec to initialize the pool with
        Returns:
        A pooled instance of SecureRandom
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - When poolSpec or prngSpec are null
        NoSuchAlgorithmException - When the random number generator is not available
        FactoryException - When the configured provider is not registered in the security provider list, or when the pool operation fails
        IllegalStateException - When the pool is reset in parallel thread, while the current thread tries to access it and borrow an object from the pool

      • returnPooledInstance

        public static void returnPooledInstance(SecureRandomSpec prngSpec,
                                        SecureRandom secureRandom)
                                 throws IllegalStateException
        Return a pooled instance back to the pool.

        Note that the pooled objects are standard JCA classes, and hence do not implement the Closeable interface. Use this method to return an object back to the pool for reuse.

        As this factory may potentially manage several pools of objects with equal type that have been created with varying specifications, provide the object spec used to create the pooled object, thus allowing this method to identify the correct pool to return the object to.

        Parameters:
        prngSpec - The object spec used to create the pooled object
        secureRandom - The object to be returned to the pool
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - When prngSpec or secureRandom are null
        IllegalStateException - If no pool exists for the provided object spec, or if an object is returned to to the wrong pool (i.e. the wrong prngSpec})

      • getPoolStats

        public static PoolStats getPoolStats(SecureRandomSpec prngSpec)
        Return the statistics of a specific pool for a certain object spec.

        As this factory may potentially manage several pools of objects of equal type that have been created with varying specifications, provide the object spec used to create the pooled object, thus allowing this method to identify the correct pool to return stats for.

        Parameters:
        prngSpec - The object spec used to create the pooled object
        Returns:
        a PoolStats object with the usage statistics of the pool identified by the provided spec
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - When prngSpec is null
        IllegalStateException - If no pool exists for the provided object spec

      • reset

        public static void reset()
        Resets the internal state of the factory. This includes resetting the pool, which causes the following methods to return new SecureRandom instances the next time they are called:

        • getSingleton(SecureRandomSpec)
        • getPooledInstance(SecureRandomSpec, PoolSpec)
